unnormalised: Okay, so you want to know how to find the address for, say, the local passport office or maybe the nearest branch of the State Bank of India? It can be a bit of a pain, especially if you’re relying on just Google. I’ve found that sometimes the online info is outdated or just plain wrong! And don't even get me started on trying to decipher those sarkari websites; they can be a real maze.

unnormalised: First, check the official website of the department or institution you're looking for. For instance, if you need the address for the regional EPFO office, go to the EPFO website (good luck navigating it!). Often, they'll have a "Contact Us" or "Locate Us" section. You might find listings there. But always double-check because sometimes "Sector 62, Noida, 201309" on the site might actually be Sector 63 due to a typo. This happened to my friend, Rajesh. He went all the way to sector 62 only to find out the office had moved to sector 63 a year ago.

You might find listings there. But always double-check because sometimes "Sector sixty two, Noida, two hundred and thirteen thousand and nine" on the site might actually be Sector sixty three due to a typo. This happened to my friend, Rajesh. He went all the way to sector sixty two only to find out the office had moved to sector sixty three a year ago.

unnormalised: Another trick is to look for official documents or circulars issued by the government or institution. These documents often include the full address of the relevant departments. For example, a recent government notification about Aadhaar updates might mention the address of the UIDAI regional office, like "UIDAI Regional Office, Tech Park, Bangalore, 560066". This can be a more reliable source than just a random Google search.

unnormalised: Don't underestimate the power of good old-fashioned networking! Ask your friends, family, or colleagues if they've ever had to visit that particular government office. They might have the exact address or even better, detailed directions! My neighbour, Mrs. Sharma, knew exactly where the MTNL office was in Andheri (E), Mumbai - "Opposite the railway station, near the flyover". Google Maps couldn't have given me that kind of helpful info.

unnormalised: Finally, if all else fails, try calling the helpline or customer service number listed on the official website. It might take a while to get through, but you can directly ask for the full address, including the pin code. Just be patient and polite, and hopefully, the person on the other end will be able to help you out. Remember to confirm the complete address, including landmark if any. Sometimes even the pin codes aren't correctly updated online like the correct pin code for the Bombay Stock Exchange is 400001, not 400023 as many portals show! Good luck finding those addresses!
